verses.text: Wine is a mocker, strong drink a brawler, and whoever is led astray by them is not wise.
verses.comment: The danger of alcohol leading people away from wisdom is emphasized. The language suggests moral alertness, a theme also expanded in New Testament teaching on sobriety (cf. 1 Tim. 5:23).

verses.text: The terror of a king is like the roar of a lion; whoever provokes him risks his own life.
verses.comment: Resisting authority leads to grave consequences. The principle points towards respect for earthly rulers as a reflection of obedience to God, foreshadowing order in the Church and family (cf. Rom. 13:1-2).

verses.text: It is a man’s honor to avoid strife, but every fool is quick to quarrel.
verses.comment: Peace-making is commended, anticipating Christ’s teaching on peacemakers and the unity desired among His followers.

verses.text: A sluggard does not plow in season; so at harvest he looks, but finds nothing.
verses.comment: The call to diligence mirrors spiritual preparedness, recalling Christ’s parables about readiness for final judgment (Matt. 25:1-13).

verses.text: The purposes in a person’s heart are deep waters, but a wise man draws them out.
verses.comment: Interpreting the inner workings of the heart requires wisdom, echoing the biblical theme of seeking counsel and understanding as seen in James (James 1:5).

verses.text: Many claim their own steadfast love, but a trustworthy man who can find?
verses.comment: The rarity of true fidelity hints at the virtue of covenantal faithfulness, a foundation for lifelong commitments, and especially evokes the enduring faithfulness of Christ.

verses.text: The righteous walk in integrity; blessed are their children after them.
verses.comment: Virtue affects generations, alluding to salvation as a communal blessing, a pillar of biblical community and spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: A king who sits on the throne to judge winnows out all evil with his eyes.
verses.comment: The imagery looks forward to the Messianic king, Christ, who separates good from evil, foreshadowing final judgment in the New Testament.

verses.text: Who can say, “I have kept my heart pure; I am clean from my sin”?
verses.comment: Universal sinfulness is confessed, anticipating the New Testament doctrine that all need purification and grace (see Rom. 3:23).

verses.text: Unequal weights and unequal measures—both are detestable to the LORD.
verses.comment: Justice in commerce reflects God’s moral order, prefiguring His concern for fairness and integrity in all aspects of life.

verses.text: Even a child is known by his actions, whether his conduct is pure and right.
verses.comment: Behavior reveals character. Jesus teaches that good fruit comes from good trees, aligning moral action with internal disposition (Matthew 12:33-37).

verses.text: The hearing ear and the seeing eye—the LORD has made them both.
verses.comment: Everything good comes from God, directing gratitude and humility toward Him as source and sustainer.

verses.text: Do not love sleep, lest you grow poor; stay awake, and you will have food to spare.
verses.comment: Vigilance and diligence are promoted, which recalls the spiritual alertness urged by Christ in the Gospels (Matt. 24:42).

verses.text: ‘Bad, bad,’ says the buyer, but when he goes away, then he boasts.
verses.comment: This verse subtly exposes the deceit present in marketplaces, urging honesty and integrity that reflect God’s truth.

verses.text: There is gold, and abundance of costly stones, but lips that speak knowledge are a rare treasure.
verses.comment: Spiritual wisdom is prized above material wealth, a core biblical value and a theme prominent in Jesus’ teaching on treasures in heaven (Matt. 6:19-21).

verses.text: Take the garment of one who has given surety for a stranger, and hold it in pledge when it is for an outsider.
verses.comment: Wise caution in financial commitments guards against improvidence, echoing biblical exhortations regarding stewardship.

verses.text: Bread gained by deceit tastes sweet to a man, but afterward his mouth will be filled with gravel.
verses.comment: Short-term pleasure from wrongdoing leads to long-term regret, highlighting that true satisfaction lies in following the way of truth.

verses.text: Plans are established by counsel; by wise guidance wage war.
verses.comment: Community wisdom is necessary in decision-making, resonating with the biblical model of authoritative teaching and guidance.

verses.text: A gossip betrays secrets; do not associate with one who speaks too freely.
verses.comment: The dangers of gossip echo the broader biblical concern for controlling the tongue and living in truth.

verses.text: If someone curses his father or mother, his lamp will be snuffed out in utter darkness.
verses.comment: Honoring parents forms the basis for community life, rooted in God’s command and reflecting the spiritual order established by divine authority.

verses.text: An inheritance obtained too early in life will not be blessed at the end.
verses.comment: Premature wealth can bring misfortune, a lesson seen in the parable of the prodigal son, pointing toward the wisdom of gradual growth and maturity.

verses.text: Do not say, ‘I will repay evil!’ Wait for the LORD, and he will deliver you.
verses.comment: Refusing vengeance reflects God’s justice and mercy, prefiguring the command of Christ to forgive even one’s enemies (Matt. 5:38-48).

verses.text: Unequal weights are detestable to the LORD, and dishonest scales are not good.
verses.comment: This repeats the principle of justice in business, revealing God’s unwavering concern for fairness and truth.

verses.text: A man’s steps are directed by the LORD. How then can anyone understand his own way?
verses.comment: Human plans are subject to God’s will. This pattern of divine guidance anticipates a life of trust and confidence in providence.

verses.text: It is a snare to dedicate something rashly and later reconsider what you have vowed.
verses.comment: The seriousness of vows points toward the sacredness of promise and the spiritual wisdom of measured commitment.

verses.text: A wise king scatters the wicked and drives the threshing wheel over them.
verses.comment: Righteous authority purges evil, a motif fulfilled in Christ as King and Judge who will separate wheat from chaff.

verses.text: The spirit of man is the lamp of the LORD, searching all the inner depths of his heart.
verses.comment: God’s intimate knowledge of the heart calls for daily examination and the pursuit of spiritual growth.

verses.text: Loyal love and faithfulness preserve the king, and his throne is upheld by righteousness.
verses.comment: Virtue both sustains personal and communal authority, echoing the enduring reign of Christ established by justice.

verses.text: The glory of young men is their strength, but the beauty of old men is their gray hair.
verses.comment: Both youth and age are honored, reflecting the biblical motif that wisdom and strength, united, bless the community.

verses.text: Blows and wounds cleanse away evil, and beatings purge the innermost parts.
verses.comment: Discipline as a means of purification echoes the biblical principle of loving correction as necessary for holiness and growth in virtue.
